results.title: The Shed
results.brief_description: ‘The Shed’ is a 2D hand-drawn animation. A humurous tale of an alien occupied spaceship that arrives on a farm on earth and offers his greetings. He finds an unhatched egg attractive and proceeds to leave earth with the egg.

results.title: Metamorphosis
results.brief_description: A colour 2D hand-drawn computer animation in response to the project theme of metamorphosis. A head changes into many things. His hair blows in the wind whilst his nose grows until the head becomes a pumpkin… An all encompassing visual play on the titles meaning. (No credits available).

results.title: The Hairy bird
results.creator_credit: Sarah Kernochan, Peter Newman, Ira Deutchman, Redeemable Features and Alliance Communications
results.brief_description: A fun romp set in 1960s middle-class white America, in a private girls’ school that is set to become co-educational. Odette is a new student and finds herself a fish-out-of-water until she embraces her new roommates and friends learning of the girls’ secret society - the D.A.R. (Daughters of American Ravioli) a reference to the cans of cold pasta they pilfer from the school kitchens via their secret attic dwelling. The girls go about ruining the imposed decision that they merge with the boys at St Ambrose by sabotaging the school dance and becoming politically active, much to the pleasure of the strict but approachable headmistress (Lynn Redgrave). At Miss Godard’s School for Girls this coming-of-age tale is full of sass and toe-tapping fun. Written and directed by Sarah Kernochan. Cast includes: Kirsten Dunst, Gaby Hoffman, Rachel Leigh Cook, Vincent Kartheiser, Monica Keena, Heather Matarazzo, and Merritt Wever.

results.title: Job evaluation and merit rating
results.creator_credit: Art Babbitt, Edward L. Gershman, Academy Productions and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”.
Situations in an industrial plant are used to show the value of analysing accurately the type of work required in jobs on different levels and of rating objectively the performances of individual employees at their assigned tasks.

results.title: Man for the job
results.creator_credit: Margaret Smith, Gregory Clegg and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Personnel Management”.
Explains job analysis and techniques of ability testing, illustrated by two case studies of applications from the personnel manager’s point of view.

results.title: Artists of Eldorado
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Shelley Matulick, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet local artists Maureen Hearn, Denise Ellison, Thea Day, Sandra Buchan and Sam Anderson, and learn about their inspirations and artistic practice. Moved by the magic of Eldorado, in northern Victoria, these artists are never short of inspiration. Day, Ellison and Buchan make time each week to get together and share their passion for painting and line drawing. Hearn works out of her studio that showcases her love of the river and obsession with chickens. Anderson is a metal sculptor who works on his family farm creating large scale works, such as his ‘Gorilla’, which must be seen to be believed.

results.title: Clash of opinion
results.creator_credit: Margaret Smith, Gregory Clegg and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”.
Discusses the role of personnel management in industrial disputes. A dispute between management and members of a Transport Union is examined. A panel of directors of companies, trade unionists and personnel managers give opinions of how the dispute arose. Stresses the need for good communications between employers and unions and better education on negotiation for shop stewards. A good personnel manager can play an important day to day role in the creation of good relations between workers and management over a long period.

results.title: Metamorphosis: BM
results.brief_description: A 2D hand-drawn animation that responds to the set theme of metamorphosis. Animator Ben McGill morphs his initials into Mr. Ogilvy, a snail and then to a dinosaur.
